newsitem.title: UK: Hair of the cat convicts suspect.
newsitem.headline: Hair of the cat convicts suspect.

text.p: Scientists said on Wednesday they used genetic fingerprinting and a cat's hair to convict a Canadian man of murder.
Marilyn Menotti-Raymond and colleagues at the Laboratory of Genomic Diversity at the U.S. National Cancer Institute in Frederick, Maryland said the case set a legal precedent.
"The case concerned a 32-year-old woman who disappeared from her home in Richmond, Prince Edward island, Canada on 3 October 1994," they wrote in a letter to the science journal Nature.

"Her abandoned car was discovered within days, and blood found inside was shown to match the victim. Three weeks later a man's leather jacket stained with the victim's blood was discovered in woods eight km from her home. In the lining several white domestic cat hairs were found."
The woman's body was later found in a shallow grave and the man she had lived with but had since been estranged from was arrested. They had a white cat named Snowball, Menotti-Raymond said.
Her laboratory used standard forensic DNA techniques to match the DNA from the cat hairs in the jacket to Snowball's blood. They presented their findings in court.
"The jury convicted the defendant of second-degree murder," they wrote.
